title: Teaching
text:
I am teaching the following courses at Carnegie Mellon University (order by course level):

46–926 Machine Learning I (mini)
Core course on statistical machine learning for the Master’s in Computational Finance program, including regression, classification, and tree-based methods.


36–613 Data Visualization (mini)
Core course in Master of Statistical Practice program on creating and understanding data visualizations and interactive tools from a statistical perspective.


36-493 Sports Analytics Capstone
Undergraduate capstone course using data provided by CMU athletics for sports analytics research projects.


36-315 Statistical Graphics and Visualization
Undergraduate course on creating and understanding data visualizations from a statistical perspective.

title: Mike Diessner
text:
I am a second-year PhD student in Computing at Newcastle University in the United Kingdom. Within the university, I am part of the Cloud Computing for Big Data CDT and the Fluid Dynamics Lab.

My research focuses on computer emulators and optimisation of physical experiments and computer simulations.

title: About
text:
I am an Assistant Teaching Professor in the Department of Statistics & Data Science at Carnegie Mellon University. My research focuses on developing methods at the interface of inference and machine learning, oriented towards problems in statistical genetics and sports analytics.
I previously received my PhD in Statistics at Carnegie Mellon University under supervision of Professor Kathryn Roeder and Max G’Sell. My thesis work focused on selective inference approaches for augmenting genetic association studies with data-guided hypothesis testing.
I also actively publish research on statistics in sports, and have developed multiple R packages to enable easy access of publicly available data. Additionally, Rebecca Nugent, Sam Ventura, and I co-organize the annual Carnegie Mellon Sports Analytics Conference which promotes the latest sports analytics research and features a reproducible research competition.

Research Interests

Statistics in Sports
Statistical Genetics
Selective Inference
Clustering



Education


Carnegie Mellon University
PhD in Statistics
Advisors: Kathryn Roeder and Max G’Sell


Pittsburgh, PA
Granted May 2022



Dissertation: Selective inference approaches for augmenting genetic association studies with multi-omics metadata



Carnegie Mellon University
BS in Statistics with University Honors


Pittsburgh, PA
Granted Dec 2015

title: Mike Diessner
text:
Teaching
I worked as a teaching assistant on the following courses:
Computing Foundations of Data Science
Postgraduate-level module teaching the fundamentals of programming in Python.
Data Management and Exploratory Data Analysis
Postgraduate-level module teaching students all necessary tools to analyse data with R.
Statistics for Empirical Psychology
Undergraduate-level module teaching fundamental statistics to psychology students (linear regression, mixed-effects model, hypothesis testing, etc.).

title: Mike Diessner
text:
Education


PhD in Computing
Newcastle University
Advisors: Richard D. Whalley and Kevin Wilson


Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom
June 2021 - Present



Investigation of Bayesian optimisation for expensive-to-evaluate black box functions.
Application to computer simulations and physical experiments in engineering to find optimal active blowing strategies to maximise drag reduction.
Award of full studentship including a stipend, tuition, research costs (equipment, publishing fees, conference fees, etc.), and travel and lodging for national and international conferences (approx. £89,000).





PGDip in Computing
Newcastle University


Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom
September 2020 - May 2021






MSc in Statistics
University of Exeter


Exeter, United Kingdom
September 2019 - August 2020



Thesis: “Using Agent-based Modelling to Estimate Personal Exposure to PM2.5 in Devon”.
Developed model was later used in the paper “A Data Integration Approach to Estimating Personal Exposures to Air Pollution” (Thomas et al., 2022).
Awards:

Dean’s Commedation: For performance at the top end of the First Class range.
MSc Academic Award: For the best overall performance on a postgraduate Mathematics programme in 2020 (£100).






BSc in Economics
University of Bonn


Bonn, Germany
September 2014 - February 2018



Thesis: “Universal basic income and its effects on the labour market in Germany”.
